title.value: Differential and overlapping effects between exogenous and endogenous attention shape perceptual facilitation during visual processing
title.justification: This is the title of the paper as stated in the beginning of the document.
title.quote:
Title
Differential and overlapping effects between exogenous and endogenous attention shape perceptual facilitation during visual processing

extractions.description: The paper investigates how exogenous (involuntary) and endogenous (voluntary) attention affect perceptual facilitation during visual processing. The study uses spatial cueing of visuospatial attention, electroencephalography (EEG), and multivariate pattern analysis (MVPA) to uncover differential and similar neural processes of both attention types at various times after stimuli. The paper links these processes to perception by examining behavioral effects using mediation analyses with single-trial event-related potentials.

type.justification: The paper involves experimental methods, data collection, and statistical analysis to derive conclusions about the neural mechanisms underlying perceptual facilitation by exogenous and endogenous attention.
type.quote: In the current work, we investigated the differential and overlapping effects of exogenous and endogenous attention on visual processing. We combined spatial cueing of visuospatial attention, electroencephalography (EEG), and multivariate pattern analysis (MVPA) to examine where and when the effects of exogenous and endogenous attention were maximally different and maximally similar.

name.justification: The study focuses on brain mechanisms involved in attention and perceptual processes using techniques such as EEG and MVPA, which are central to neuroscience research.
name.quote: Visuospatial attention is not a monolithic process and can be divided into different functional systems... we investigated the differential and overlapping effects of exogenous and endogenous attention on visual processing.

name.justification: The study investigates cognitive processes like attention and perception, examining their neural underpinnings using advanced electrophysiological techniques.
name.quote: Visuospatial attention is not a monolithic process and can be divided into different functional systems... we investigated the differential and overlapping effects of exogenous and endogenous attention on visual processing.

name.justification: The study employs SVM classifiers in its multivariate pattern analysis to decode differences and similarities in neural responses associated with exogenous and endogenous attention.
name.quote: Our multivariate statistical analyses largely follow from the work of Bae and Luck (2018). Here, we performed multivariate classification using linear support vector machine (SVM) and MATLAB’s fitcsvm and predict functions.

is_contributed.justification: The SVM model is not introduced as a novel contribution in this paper; it is a pre-existing method used for analysis.
is_contributed.quote: Our multivariate statistical analyses largely follow from the work of Bae and Luck (2018). Here, we performed multivariate classification using linear support vector machine (SVM) and MATLAB’s fitcsvm and predict functions.

is_executed.justification: The SVM models were executed as part of the study's analysis pipeline to decode neural activity patterns.
is_executed.quote: Here, we performed multivariate classification using linear support vector machine (SVM) and MATLAB’s fitcsvm and predict functions.

is_compared.justification: The SVM models' performance is evaluated to decode differences between exogenous and endogenous attention, effectively comparing them indirectly through decoding accuracy.
is_compared.quote: We wanted to verify if classifiers trained on exogenous attention generalized to endogenous attention, and vise-versa.
